required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Impact of Suction- Assisted Laryngoscopy and Airway Decontamination on Intubation Times
clinical_study.official_title: The Impact of Suction- Assisted Laryngoscopy and Airway Decontamination on Intubation Times

brief_summary.textblock: A study was formulated to test the hypothesis that comprehensive training in Suction- Assisted Laryngoscopy and Airway Decontamination techniques reduces mannequin intubation times for Anaesthesia trainees.

detailed_description.textblock: To assess the clinical impact of in Suction- Assisted Laryngoscopy and Airway Decontamination (SALAD) training among 37 anaesthesia trainees. Intubation mannequin will be used to assess intubation times for contaminated airways pre and post SALAD training.

primary_outcome.measure: Time to intubation as preformed on a mannequin .
primary_outcome.description: Aim to investigate whether specific airway training on contaminated airways reduced intubation time in anaesthesia trainees.

arm_group.description: Each trainee was asked to intubate a mannequin with a contaminated airway
Each trainee was asked to intubate a mannequin with a contaminated airway after receiving SALAD training

intervention.intervention_name: Training on Suction Assisted Laryngoscopy and Airway Decontamination
intervention.description: Education on Suction Assisted Laryngoscopy and Airway Decontamination, via 30 minute teaching session, followed by practical demonstration of techniques.

intervention.intervention_name: No Training on Suction Assisted Laryngoscopy and Airway Decontamination Provided
intervention.description: No Training on Suction Assisted Laryngoscopy and Airway Decontamination provided to trainees

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
All Anaesthesia trainees employment in Mater Misericordiae University hospital during the month of August 2019 - October 2019 were invited to partake in the study.
Exclusion Criteria:
All intensive care trainees with no training in intubation were excluded from the study.
